nodes.text: An IoT-based home automation system can provide low-cost wireless control of home appliances, improve energy performance and user convenience, increase accessibility for elderly and disabled users, and be scalable and remotely accessible via WiFi-enabled devices
Design and implement an interconnected network of home appliances integrated into a Home Automation System (HAS) to automate control of every appliance
Develop an application with switch and voice control modes that displays appliance status and runs on WiFi-capable devices (Android, iOS, PC)
Prototype should be highly scalable to allow adding and integrating additional functions and devices
A low-cost prototype using Arduino UNO, Bluetooth HC-05, relay modules, WiFi, and Android client with socket programming can realize the HAS functionality

IoT-based approaches in prior literature use NodeMCU or Raspberry Pi, MQTT or web services, Google Assistant and voice integration, and demonstrate feasibility of remote smart home control and security features
Hardware and software components specified: Arduino IDE and server software; Arduino UNO R3, Bluetooth HC-05, relay module, PCB, wires, power supply, and WiFi
Automating appliance control reduces human error (e.g., forgetting to turn off lights), lowers electricity waste, and aids mobility-impaired users

The Android app implements two control modes: Switch Mode sending radio-button state via sockets, and Voice Mode using smartphone microphone to obtain voice text from Google servers which is parsed and processed
Control of appliances can be performed from any WiFi-capable device, enabling remote access over internet or intranet
The app displays the status of each device and supports voice command-based switching of appliances
Prototype design is simple, economical, easy to expand, and intended for deployment in homes, small offices, and shopping centers

Prototype implementation features: wireless remote switching via WiFi with approximate indoor range 150 feet, ability to toggle devices via app or voice, and secure connections using SSL over TCP or SSH
Empirical outcomes: the prototype successfully demonstrates WiFi remote switching, voice control, status display, secure communication, and cost-effectiveness for a proof-of-concept HAS

Limitations and assumptions include existing challenges of cost and complexity in broader adoption, reliance on continuous WiFi availability and external voice recognition services, and prototype evaluation limited to indoor range and basic appliances

Conclusion: An IoT-based, Android-driven prototype using affordable hardware and voice/switch interfaces can realize a scalable, remote-accessible home automation system that improves energy use and accessibility while remaining economical
